title: National Weather Service talks 2024 hurricane season outlook
message:
The waters around Hawaiʻi will likely see a mild hurricane season with one to four tropical cyclones across the central Pacific region, according to forecasters.
Hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.
This year's below-average prediction is due to a quick transition from El Niño to La Niña conditions, scientists with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Tuesday.
The hurricane season also overlaps with high risks of wildfires in the summer.
Hawaiʻi Public Radio Meteorologist John Bravender, right, with The Conversation host Catherine Cruz at Hawaiʻi Public Radio on May 22, 2024.
event_breakdown: 1. Hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through Nov. 30. (location is in the central Pacific region)

title: This county is 75 % complete with a flood mitigation project
message:
Orange County has already hauled out 23,000 dump trucks worth of dirt from the ponds to help minimize flooding during the rainy season.
The active construction site said there is still some work to do, but it plans to survive the next hurricane season.
Lifelong Orlovista resident Levi Williams recalls the stress of cleanup after Hurricane Ian’s floodwaters overwhelmed her home.
Mike Drozeck from the stormwater management division in Orange County said the $23 million project is nearing the finish line.
However, there is a supply chain issue, which means permanent pumps won’t be installed before hurricane season—that’s why the county has authorized more than $600,000 to implement an emergency plan.

title: Satellites capture smoke pouring from hundreds of wildfires across North America ( photos )
message:
Hundreds of wildfires have been blazing across Canada and Mexico since last week, and new satellite images released by NASA show the smoke pouring out of some.
NASA's Terra satellite, which is a small, school-bus-sized satellite circling Earth since 1999, imaged smoke from multiple fires in British Columbia and Alberta.
Last year's wildfire season was the country's worst on record, when more than 45 million acres burned across the country.
However, less intense drought conditions compared to last year are expected to make this year's wildfire season less extreme, according to one New York Times article.
A view of wildfire smoke from a spaceborne perspective.

- More than 45 million acres burned across the country due to wildfires in 2021

title: State leaders discuss hurricane mitigation program during Extreme Wind Conference
message:
(WLOX) - With hurricane season just one week away, state leaders are working to make sure residents across South Mississippi are prepared for anything.
During the Extreme Wind Conference, Mississippi Insurance Commissioner Mike Chaney said the focus is on what cities and counties should of after experiencing straight-line winds, hurricanes, or tornados.
Commissioner Chaney said the bill transfers $5 million from the Mississippi Surplus Lines Association to the Comprehensive Hurricane Damage Mitigation Program Fund.
The next level is a brace you can buy and have permanently installed and you just pop it into place when a hurricane comes.

title: From Zambia to Afghanistan , WFP warns El Nino extreme weather is causing a surge in hunger | iNFOnews
message:
From Zambia to Afghanistan, WFP warns El Nino's extreme weather is causing a surge in hungerAn Afghan couple sit near to their damaged home after heavy flooding in Ghor province in western Afghanistan Saturday, May 18, 2024.
Tens of millions of people in southern Africa rely on the weather to grow food to feed themselves.
In a statement, the WFP warned that southern Africa was the “epicenter of the crisis” after a cycle of floods and drought has battered the region over the last three years.
In a joint statement, the southern African countries said the region needed $5.5 billion to help more than 61 million people.
Countries that depend on hydroelectric generators, like Zambia, are struggling to produce enough electricity because of the drought.

title: Iowa DNR urge public to avoid floodwaters
message:
DES MOINES, Iowa (KCRG) - After several days of heavy rainfall, flash flooding, and yesterday’s storms, multiple wastewater treatment plants in the state have reported discharging untreated or partially treated wastewater.
The Iowa DNR has received 131 reports of discharges at wastewater treatment facilities since April 1st, with 44 of those occurring in the last 5 days.
Officials say these discharges can result from heavy precipitation, power outages, and storm damage overloading their collection systems.
Officials urge that people and pets avoid these areas and stay out of flooded and elevated waterways due to safety concerns at this time.
DNR staff say they will continue to monitor these situations and provide assistance to impacted communities.
event_breakdown: Heavy precipitation, power outages, and storm damage.

The Denton fire wasn’t mentioned during the first half of the Energy and Telecommunication Interim Committee, which concerned wildfire liability.
The wildfires caused by utilities are a national issue, said Mark Lambrecht, of Montana Rural Electric Cooperatives.
Chris Pope, a Democratic Senator from Bozeman, recalled that at an earlier meeting NorthWestern characterized wildfire policy as a high priority.

title: What is La Nina , expected to set in later this year , and how it could impact global weather
message:
Last month, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecasted above-normal rain in the upcoming monsoon season in India, with “favourable” La Nina conditions expected to set in by August-September.
What are El Niño and La Nina?
Thus, climatologically, El Niño and La Nina are opposite phases of what is collectively called the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle.
How could the incoming La Nina impact global weather?
Thereafter, La Nina conditions are expected to emerge and its impact could be effective from August.

title: Victims of Kenya floods include unreached people groups
message:
Kenya (MNN) — Heavy rainfall continues to plague Kenya.
The deluge is causing floods and landslides across 80 percent of the country.
The floods have displaced more than 280,000 people since early April, and at least 277 have lost their lives.
“For the better part of the last couple of decades, so much of Kenya has been in drought,” Unknown Nations’ Greg Kelley says.

title: Simpsonville Mayor in D . C . advocating for flooding funding

title: NOAA expects below - normal hurricane season in central Pacific
message:
The first outlook for the 2024 hurricane season in the central Pacific has been released, and for Hawaiian residents, a developing La Niña is expected to dictate how busy the season will be.
NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center, in coordination with the agency’s Climate Prediction Center, expects 1-4 tropical cyclones to traverse the ocean, which is below the typical 4-5 tropical depressions, tropical storms and hurricanes.
"Hurricane season in the central Pacific region is likely to be below average this year," Matthew Rosencrans, lead seasonal hurricane forecaster at NOAA’s CPC said in a statement.
2024 ATLANTIC HURRICANE SEASON GUIDE: HERE’S WHAT TO KNOW ABOUT THIS YEAR’S STORMS"As we look towards our coming hurricane season, we must prepare with the real possibility in mind that a hurricane could impact our community," Chris Brenchley, director of NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center, said in a statement.
Original article source: NOAA expects below-normal hurricane season in central Pacific
event_breakdown:
.
1. NOAA-CPC (Climate Prediction Center) - Outlook releases a forecast for a tropical season of 1-4 cyclones traversing the ocean. Saying it will be "Below-normal".

title: Derecho season ? Houston must prepare for new disasters .
message:
Raquel Natalicchio/Staff photographer Jaime Garcia, a veteran storm chaser, sits atop a tree in East Houston felled by a May 16 derecho.
Garcia had already been tracking torrential rain near College Station on May 16, when he got an alert on his phone for a tornado warning in Houston.
“It was very tough for me to see, even as a storm chaser,” Garcia told the editorial board.
In the event you’re stuck in a car during a storm, Garcia even suggested keeping a bicycle helmet in your trunk should you need to take cover.
If there’s one thing last week’s derecho proved, it’s that the paradigm for extreme weather is constantly shifting.

title: UK environmental disaster and terror response needs £100m upgrade
message:
UK disaster response needs 'urgent' £100m upgrade5 hours ago Malcolm Prior , BBC News rural affairs producer ShareGetty Images Wildfires linked to climate change are placing greater demand on fire crewsVital equipment used by firefighters to tackle environmental disasters and terror attacks needs to be “urgently” replaced at an estimated cost of £100m, the BBC has learnt.
Full details of how much specialist kit the UK has are kept secret for security reasons.
The National Fire Chiefs Council (NFCC) has estimated the full cost of replacing all the New Dimension kit would be £100m.
Kit replaced so far includes chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) detection vehicles and support equipment.
But firefighters are concerned that the 52 high-volume pumps used to deal with flooding and wildfires have yet to be upgraded or replaced.

title: 2024 hurricane season : Forecasts all point to a busy season with La Niña and warm ocean temps
message:
From the shimmering blaze of an overheated Atlantic Ocean to gales in the underbelly of the stratosphere, all evidence points to a highly active 2024 hurricane season that could rival the busiest years on record.
The 2024 hurricane season is forecast to be one of the most active on record with most predictions calling for more than 20 named storms.
Colorado State University is predicting 23 named storms, the University of Pennsylvania is forecasting between 27 and 39 named storms, with a best estimate of 33, The Weather Company issued its most aggressive outlook since it began seasonal forecasting in 2006 with 24 named storms, and AccuWeather is predicting up to 25 named storms.
The setup of warm water and El Niño was billed as a clash of titans with forecasters uncertain how the hurricane season would unfold.
This article originally appeared on Palm Beach Post: Hurricane season 2024 is forecast to be one of busiest on record

title: 2024 will be the most active hurricane season in the Atlantic : NPR
message:
The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be 'extraordinary,' forecasters warntoggle caption Joe Raedle/Getty Images/Getty Images North AmericaThis year’s Atlantic hurricane season is expected to be extremely active, putting tens of millions of Americans in the eastern half of the country at risk from flooding and damaging winds, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center warn.
Forecasters expect 17 to 25 storms to form in the Atlantic between June 1 and the end of November.
It’s the largest number of storms ever forecast for the Atlantic, and is well above the average of 14 storms that usually occur in a given hurricane season.
But the biggest factor is abnormally high water temperatures in the tropical Atlantic, where hurricanes form.
Warm water is fuel for storms, because heat provides energy for the storm’s winds and warmer water provides more moisture, leading to large, powerful and rainy storms.

title: NOAA predicts above - normal 2024 hurricane season for Atlantic - WSVN 7News | Miami News , Weather , Sports
message:
Forecasters at the NOAA Climate Prediction Center predict an above-normal hurricane season in the Atlantic basin for 2024.
The season, spanning from June 1 to November 30, has an 85% chance of above-normal activity, a 10% chance of near-normal activity, and a 5% chance of below-normal activity.
NOAA expects 17 to 25 named storms, with winds of 39 mph or higher.
8 to 13 could become hurricanes, including 4 to 7 major hurricanes with winds of 111 mph or higher.
The predicted activity is attributed to several factors, including near-record warm Atlantic Ocean temperatures, La Niña conditions in the Pacific, reduced Atlantic trade winds, and less wind shear, said NOAA.

El Niño and La Niña are the warm and cool phases of a recurring climate pattern across the tropical Pacific—the El Niño-Southern Oscillation, or “ENSO” for short.
La Niña typically increases the amount of storm activity in the Atlantic basin because it decreases the amount of vertical wind shear.
The Storm Station likes to remind that “it only takes one hurricane making landfall to make it an active season for you,” so prepare accordingly.

title: Ocean heat , La Nina likely mean more Atlantic hurricanes this summer
message:
Get ready for what nearly all the experts think will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record, thanks to unprecedented ocean heat and a brewing La Nina.
An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms — seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
A La Nina tends to turbocharge Atlantic storm activity while depressing storminess in the Pacific, and an El Nino does the opposite.
La Nina usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Nina there's more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Instead of a La Nina, there was a strong El Nino, which usually inhibits storminess a bit.

title: NOAA expects  extraordinary  2024 Atlantic hurricane season
message:
National Weather Service forecasters at the Climate Prediction Center said Thursday that there is an 85% chance of an above-average 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, compared to a 5% chance that it will be below normal.
If the forecast holds true, 2024 could be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons ever.
"This [hurricane] season is looking to be an extraordinary one," said Rick Spinrad, administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
The third-busiest Atlantic hurricane season was 2021, with 21 named storms, seven hurricanes and four major hurricanes.
Forecasters say a likely La Niña pattern coupled with warm sea-surface temperatures would lead to an "extraordinary" hurricane season.
event_breakdown: Atlantic Hurricane Season 2024.

title: Hurricane season in Atlantic to be  extraordinary
message:
The North Atlantic could get as many as seven major hurricanes of category three strength or over this year, which would be more than double the usual number, the US weather agency NOAA has warned.
Normally you'd expect three major hurricanes in a season.
As many as 13 Atlantic hurricanes of category one or above are forecast for the period, which runs from June to November.
"This [hurricane] season is looking to be an extraordinary one," NOAA administrator Rick Spinrad said in a news conference.
In contrast to the Atlantic, NOAA had already predicted a "below-normal" hurricane season, external in the central Pacific region, where a move to La Niña has the opposite effect.

title: NOAA issues highest - ever May forecast for hurricane season
message:
In the highest hurricane season forecast they have ever released in May, National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration forecasters said Thursday that the coming months may be exceptionally busy.
“The forecast for named storms, hurricanes and major hurricanes is the highest NOAA has ever issued for the May outlook,” Rick Spinrad, the agency's administrator, said in a news conference.
Hurricane season begins June 1 and ends November 30.
NOAA is far from alone in making such a prediction for this hurricane season.
The high forecast doesn’t necessarily mean that a strong hurricane will make landfall in the U.S., however.

title: NOAA & united kingdom Met Office join forecasts for  extraordinary  hurricane season
message:
The US weather service NOAA and the UK’s Met Office have both issued forecasts that join others in suggesting the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be a very active one, with each opting for storm numbers well above the average and NOAA saying it looks likely to be an “extraordinary” year.
The UK Met Office’s forecast actually came out yesterday, but we waited for NOAA’s announcement, made just now, to provide the two forecasts together for our readers.
Like every other forecaster of tropical storm and hurricane activity in the Atlantic basin for 2024, the pair are expecting the tropics to be particularly active this year.
The US weather service NOAA has just announced its figures and again they are pointing to a good deal of activity in the Atlantic tropics this hurricane season, 85% above normal activity being the prediction.
Track the 2024 Atlantic tropical storm and hurricane season on our dedicated page and we’ll update you as new information emerges.

title: More Atlantic hurricanes likely this summer , NOAA outlook reports
message:
CHARLOTTESVILLE (WVIR) - Time to prepare for what experts think will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) predicts that between 17 and 25 named storms will brew up during summer and fall, with 8 to 13 of those storms achieving hurricane status and four to seven of them becoming major hurricanes.
“Forecast modeling indicates that above average sea surface temperatures are predicted during the peak months of the Atlantic hurricane season from August to October,” NOAA Administrator Dr. Rick Spinrad said.
“The forecast for named storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes is the highest NOAA has ever issued for the May outlook.”According to the NOAA, these storms are thanks to rising ocean temperatures and a brewing La Nina.
The forecast comes as a vast area of the South has been deluged by drenching, flooding storms in recent weeks.
event_breakdown:
1. Hurricane season in the Atlantic.
2. Potential for more storms than normal.

title: Severe weather storms continue to cause havoc as tornado rips through Texas
message:
The severe weather turned south Wednesday after a deadly tornado wreaked havoc in the small city of the day before.
Severe weather storms moved through Wednesday night.
Belton police said the severe weather caused several roads throughout town to become impassible due to fallen trees and flooding.
The National Weather Service of Fort Worth plans to conduct a storm survey to assess the extent of the damages from this storm.
On Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with 21 in Iowa.
event_breakdown:
- Deadly tornado in Weslaco, Texas
- Severe weather in Belton, Texas
- 23 tornadoes were reported on Tuesday with 21 being in Iowa

title: Canada Braces for Intense Hurricane Season , Warns Gov Agency
message:
Today, Environment and Climate Change Canada's Canadian Hurricane Centre reminded Canadians that we face the prospect of a significant hurricane season ahead.
This annual Canadian update followed the release of the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Hurricane Centre outlook for the 2024 hurricane season.
The hurricane season officially runs from June 1 to November 30.
The Canadian Hurricane Centre and the NOAA work closely together to promote hurricane safety and preparedness throughout the season.
These are the highest numbers that NOAA has ever predicted during a spring hurricane season outlook.

title: NOAA predicts record hurricane season for 2024 - WEIS | Local & Area News , Sports , & Weather
message:
George Doyle/Getty Images(NEW YORK) — The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has issued its highest-on record May hurricane forecast for the upcoming hurricane season.
All categories of storms are expected to exceed the typical number seen every year, National Weather Service forecasters announced Thursday in a news conference for the 2024 hurricane outlook.
Multiple officials, including National Hurricane Center Director Michael Brennan and National Weather Service Director Ken Graham, described the 2024 Hurricane Outlook as the “highest” forecast ever issued in May.
The Atlantic hurricane season starts June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.
Climate change is likely having a significant impact on the Atlantic hurricane season, according to researchers.

This well above average prediction is in-line with the hurricane predictions released by Colorado State earlier this year.
Regardless of the forecast, it’s best to prepare for EVERY hurricane season because it only takes one storm to make it a bad season for you.

title: Louisiana crawfish harvest down as much as 90 % in shortage that could cripple industry for years
message:
articleThe U.S. Department of Agriculture approved emergency financial relief for struggling crawfish farmers and fisherman for a 2024 harvest that is down 50-90% across Louisiana, according to the Louisiana State University Agricultural Center .
Crawfish season is winding down across Louisiana , which produces about the majority of the nation's crawfish every year, according to the Louisiana Crawfish Promotion and Research Board .

The crawfish industry needs all the support it can get right now."

title: Atlantic could see as many as 13 hurricanes this season , forecasters warn
message:
The Atlantic basin — which spans the Atlantic Ocean, the Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico — could see up to 13 hurricanes between June 1 and Nov. 30, a number forecasters say would be more than normal.
Forecasters are predicting 17 to 25 named storms, where winds are 39 mph or higher.
Of those, eight to 13 could be hurricanes, storms where winds reach speeds of 74 mph or more.
The season could also see as many as seven “major” hurricanes with winds of 111 mph or higher.
A summary infographic showing hurricane season probability and numbers of named storms predicted from NOAA's 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season Outlook.Courtesy NOAAForecasters said they had 70% confidence in those ranges.

.
* An above-average hurricane season is predicted in the Atlantic basin from June 1 to Nov. 30, 2024.

title: How is climate change affecting hurricanes , typhoons and cyclones ?
message:
Globally, the frequency of tropical cyclones has not increased, and in fact the number may have fallen - although long-term data is limited in some regions.
[BBC]It quotes "medium confidence" that there has been an increase in the average and peak rainfall rates associated with tropical cyclones.
In some places, the average location where tropical cyclones reach their peak intensity has shifted poleward - for example the western North Pacific.
Assessing the precise influence of climate change on individual tropical cyclones is challenging.
The number of tropical cyclones globally is unlikely to increase, according to the IPCC.

On Oct. 17, 2022, the department initially awarded a National Dislocated Worker Grant of $15 million to the Florida Department of Commerce, followed by an additional $7.5 million in incremental funding on Oct. 2, 2023, to provide temporary employment for eligible individuals, assisting in debris removal, humanitarian aid and cleanup work.
The grant also supported career and training services for area workers.
Hurricane Ian, a Category 4 hurricane, struck Florida’s southwest coast in September 2022, bringing high winds, storm surges and massive flooding.

Demand For Catastrophe-Resistant Building Materials Soars
Building code changes in recent years call for structures to be able to stand up to intense wind and flooding.
Some states have done it themselves, but many others are waiting for the federal government to do it for them.
The desire for windows so strong they can bend and flex is growing as stronger regulations move into the market.
Lumber is becoming less popular, while companies such as Saint-Gobain and AGNORA are selling glass systems that can flex without breaking.
Installing hurricane-resistant glass windows is more costly than cheap wood framing, and it costs $6,000–$8,000 per window to fix them.
But the expected lifespan of these thick, impact-resistant windows is as long as 40 years.
  -----
5. What are storm surges?
Surges are big, destructive waves powered by fierce winds. As hurricanes move across shallow areas of the ocean, significant changes in the water level can occur. The change in pressure can dislodge the water, creating a higher water level.
Before the eye of the storm hits, water levels may rise between one and two meters in low-lying areas. Water can flood the floors of buildings, trees can be pulled straight out of the ground, and sometimes structures or parts of a structure may collapse.
Passengers who survive storm surges are often able to recover from their injuries, especially if the building was destroyed.
But there are still some risks involved even if a building misses the surge or is still standing.

title: Confidence High for Above - Normal Atlantic Hurricane Season
message:
The hurricane season, which runs from June 1 to November 30, has an 85% probability of above-normal activity—the highest confidence forecasters have had in any above-average seasonal outlook—with a 10% chance of being near-normal and only a 5% chance of falling below-normal.
These include near-record warm ocean temperatures in the Atlantic Ocean, the development of La Nina conditions in the Pacific, reduced Atlantic trade winds, and decreased wind shear.
NOAA scientists expect a quick transition to La Nina conditions, which tend to lessen wind shear in the tropics and are conducive to Atlantic hurricane activity.
This, coupled with abundant oceanic heat content in the tropical Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea, creates more energy to fuel storm development.
This hurricane season may also see an above-normal west African monsoon, leading to African easterly waves that seed some of the strongest and longest-lived Atlantic storms.

title: Forecasters predict  hyperactive  hurricane season
message:
GEORGETOWN, Guyana (CMC) — Regional forecasters Thursday predicted a “hyperactive” 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season with up to 29 named storms, 13 of which are likely to become hurricanes, including seven major hurricanes.
Presenting the outlook, Specialist Meteorologist at Hydrometeorological Service of Guyana, Komalchand Dhiram, said that Saharan dust is likely to impact cyclone activity during the earlier part of the hurricane season.
“With no intrusion or very limited intrusion of the Saharan dust, a hyperactive 2024 Atlantic Hurricane season is anticipated,” he said, noting that the CIMH is only able to forecast Sharan dust intrusion up to two weeks in advance.
And that is because as we move away from August, the intrusion of Saharan dust decreases,” Dhiram explained.
For The Weather Co, the forecast is 25 named storms, 12 hurricanes and six major hurricanes, according to its May 16 outlook.

title: Active storm season predicted for East Coast , Canadian Hurricane Centre says
message:
Open this photo in gallery: Buildings sit in the water along the shore following hurricane Fiona in Rose Blanche-Harbour le Cou, N.L., on Sept. 27, 2022.Frank Gunn/The Canadian PressThe Canadian Hurricane Centre is predicting an active storm season off the country’s East Coast this year, mainly due to record warm water temperatures in the Atlantic Ocean.
In a briefing today, meteorologist Bob Robichaud says the water temperatures are also expected to be affected by La Nina, a cooling of surface water temperature in the Pacific Ocean that typically produces more storms in the Atlantic.
He says Canadian waters typically see about 35 per cent of the storms that form in the Atlantic Basin, although in any given year that average can vary wildly.
Robichaud says it’s still too early to say how many of the predicted storms could affect Atlantic Canadian communities.
The official hurricane season starts June 1 and runs until Nov. 30.

title: Heat dome  brings sweltering temperatures to Florida , Mexico , Central America
message:
Extreme heat in Mexico, Central America and parts of the U.S. South has left millions of people in sweltering temperatures, strained energy grids and resulted in iconic Howler monkeys in Mexico dropping dead from trees.
The high temperatures are stretching across the Gulf of Mexico into parts of the United States, including Texas and Florida.
Temperatures along the Rio Grande were expected to rise up to 111 degrees Fahrenheit and 95 degrees Fahrenheit in the Davis and Chinati mountains.
Experts say the heat event raises concerns about ocean water temperatures and their influence on the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season.
Nearby nations including Guatemala, Belize, El Salvador, Honduras, the Dominican Republic and Haiti are also experiencing abnormally warm temperatures due to this area of high pressure.
event_breakdown: Extreme Heat across Mexico, Central America and the U.S. South; Howler monkeys dropping dead in extreme heat; Gulf of Mexico waters heat up in area of high pressure; Temperatures rise across Mexico, U.S. Gulf states and Chinati mountains; Upcoming Atlantic Hurricane Season concerns

title: Mainers warned of  ping pong ball sized  hail during Thursday storms
message:
Mainers in central Aroostook County are being warned of “ping pong ball” sized hail on Thursday during thunderstorms sweeping across the state.
The storm will vary in intensity, but will likely bring hail and wind gusts up to 60 miles per hour to the region, according to the Caribou office of the National Weather Service.
A severe thunderstorm warning is in place throughout the Caribou region, the Augusta region and Thorndike area, but is expected to expire by 3:30 p.m.Hail can damage vehicles and buildings, as well as injure people and pets.
The storm system is also bringing torrential rain, which could lead to flash flooding.
A severe thunderstorm watch remains in place for most of the state until 7 p.m. this evening.
event_breakdown:
- Severe Thunderstorm Warning for Aroostook County
- Tornado Warning
- Flash Flood Warning

title: Severe storms to pose risk to lives and property through Memorial Day
message:
Disruptive and dangerous thunderstorms will erupt and advance from the central United States to the East Coast during the Memorial Day weekend, AccuWeather meteorologists warn.
Chicago will be at moderate risk of severe thunderstorms and a tornado on Friday.
St. Louis and Lousiville, Kentucky, will be at a moderate risk of severe weather, including tornadoes, on Sunday.
While the extent of severe thunderstorms in the East on Memorial Day may be limited to parts of the region, the strongest storms still carry some risk of tornadoes.
An extreme (burgundy) risk zone is rare but signifies the likelihood of an intense outbreak of severe weather.

title: 2024 Hurricane Season forecast predicts highly active season
message:
GAINESVILLE, Fla. (WCJB/NSF) - Many experts anticipate a highly active hurricane season, particularly for Florida and neighboring regions on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
The National Oceanographic Atmospheric Association, or NOAA, predicts 25 named storms for the 2024 hurricane season.
Not all named storms are hurricanes, but NOAA anticipates 13 named storms to reach hurricane strength.
RELATED: TV20 launches 24/7 weather livestreamOne meteorologist at the National Weather Service, Mark Wool, commented he supports the 2024 hurricane season forecasts.
The official hurricane season will begin on June 1st, and extends for six months to December.

title: Hurricane season forecast released
message:
The National Hurricane Center of the United States has issued their forecast for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
The forecast calls for a very active season when it comes to the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes expected.
The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season forecast issued by the National Hurricane Center as part of the National Oceangraphic and Atmospheric Administration.
(Source: National Hurricane Center)Seventeen-to-25 named storms are being forecasted.
A major hurricane has maximum sustained winds of 178 km/h or higher near its centre.

title: Hurricane Season Around the Corner : Eyes on the Atlantic
message:
23 May 2024 6:50 PMAtlantic Hurricane Season officially begins on June 1st, but there is an area of interest that the National Hurricane Center [NHC] is already monitoring.
Forecasts for the 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season call for an above-average number of storms thanks to warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures and a transition to La Nina conditions just in time for the peak of the season in September.
As mentioned above, warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures will aid in storm development.
We are roughly two months ahead of schedule according to experts when it comes to sea surface temperatures.

title: NOAA predicting  above average  2024 hurricane season in the Atlantic : Here what to expect
message:
The ingredients will be in place to make for an above-average 2024 hurricane season in the Atlantic basin, according to the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration, which released its 2024 outlook on Thursday.
“Of note, the forecast for named storms, hurricanes and major hurricanes is the highest NOAA has ever issued for the May outlook,” said NOAA Administrator Dr. Rick Spinrad.
A summary infographic showing hurricane season probability and numbers of named storms predicted from NOAA's 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season Outlook.Courtesy NOAAThe hurricane season officially starts on June 1 and ends on Nov. 30, with most activity occurring between mid-August and mid-October.
Enhanced communications planned for 2024 seasonNOAA is planning several improvements for communication during this 2024 hurricane season.
Finally, NOAA’s Weather Prediction Center, in partnership with the NHC, will issue an experimental rainfall graphic for the Caribbean and Central America during the 2024 hurricane season.

title: Rain drenching welcomed
message:
According to Environment Canada, up to 57 millimetres (mm) fell on some parts of Thunder Bay before the storm, which originated in the mid-west U.S., had dissipated.
The city normally receives about 65 mm of rain for the entire month of May.
Marcelle Paulin, who operates a vegetable farm in Pass Lake, said her rain gauge showed that 37 mm fell over the course of the storm.
"That was a lot of rain," Paulin said.
"We have been missing this type of rain in the past few years," said Tarlok Sahota, who oversees Lakehead University's agricultural research station just west of Thunder Bay.
event_breakdown:
These are the natural-disasters events mentioned in the text:
- A storm hit Thunder Bay
- A storm originating in the mid-west U.S. brought heavy rain to Thunder Bay
